meta.description: Landing page for the Graasp suite of applications on climate change
TITLE: Simulations and numerical activities to teach global warming in basic sciences
OSCILLATING_CHARGE_DESCRIPTION: Electromagnetic waves at various wavelengths in UV, VIS, IR
THERMAL_RADIATION_DESCRIPTION: IR waves emitted by a planetary surface
RADIATION_ABSORPTION_DESCRIPTION: Interaction between radiation and atmospheric gas molecules
* Recommended pedagogical prerequisites:: * Recommended pedagogical prerequisites: Concepts of electric charges, atoms, molecules, energy, and power
team.text: The simulations were designed and validated by <2>Philippe Kobel</2> and <6>Thierry Gerez</6> (Physics and Chemistry teachers at Gymnase du Bugnon), with the scientific collaboration of <10>Stéphane Goyette</10> (University of Geneva) and didactic support of Yves Debernardi and <14>Nicolas Perrin</14> (Haute École Pédagogique Vaud). The interaction design and implementation were carried out by <18>Kim Lan Phan Hoang</18> and <22>Hagop Taminian</22> within <26>Denis Gillet's</26> group at EPFL (École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne), and were consolidated in collaboration with <30>Graasp.org</30>.
Left to right: Stéphane Goyette, Denis G: Left to right: Stéphane Goyette, Denis Gillet, Thierry Gerez, Kim Lan Phan Hoang, Philippe Kobel, Yves Debernardi, and Nicolas Perrin.
Approved by the International Year of Ba: Approved by the International Year of Basic Sciences for Sustainable Development 2022
GLOBAL_MODEL_DESCRIPTION: Radiative balance with greenhouse gases, clouds and surface
Based on climate education research • Ad: Based on climate education research • Adapted for middle and high schools • Tested in classrooms • Easily embedded in Graasp activities and other web platforms
CONTACT_FORM_TEXT: We'll be more than happy to hear about your suggestion or feedback regarding your use of the simulations. It will help for further improvements. Write an email to us, we will reply in a few days.
TEAM_DESCRIPTION: Graasp Climate is a collaboration between teachers from various Swiss secondary schools, the Graasp association and scientific and educational advisors.
TEAM_ACKNOLEDGEMENTS: We are also grateful to the researchers who helped with their valuable inputs (Prof. D. Archer, U Colorado, Prof. A. Ohmura, ETHZ, Prof. Natalie Krivova, MPS, Prof. Michael Petterson, U Auckland).
